titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Antonio Sotomayor Papers, circa 1920-1988, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Stephanie Ashley

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Stephanie L. Ashley 2002

change.item: Finding aid updated from EAD v. 1.0 to v. 2002 by Stephanie Ashley

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The collection documents the career of painter and illustrator, Antonio Sotomayor, his interest in Latin American art and artists, and his association with the San Francisco arts community. Materials found in the collection include letters, writings, sketches and sketchbooks, printed material and photographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Antonio Sotomayor was born in Bolvia and came to San Francisco in 1923. He was educated at the Escuela de Belleas Arts in La Paz and the Hopkins Institute of Art in San Francisco. Primarily known for his murals and paintings, Sotomayor was also an illustrator, caricaturist, designer, ceramicist, and educator. Over the course of his career his work was exhibited in the United States, France, Italy, Spain, Mexico, and South America and he became known as the popular "artist laureate" of San Francisco where he lived with his wife, Grace. He died of cancer in 1985 at the age of 82.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists primarily of correspondence, writings, artwork, printed material, and photographs documenting Sotomayor's career, his interest in Latin American art and artists, and his association with the San Francisco arts community.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as six series:

list.item: Series 6: Oversized Material, 1941, 1958, undated (2 OV folders)

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following terms.

controlaccess.head: Subjects-Topical:
controlaccess.subject: Mural painting and decoration -- 20th century
Illustration

Painters -- California -- San Francisco

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Antonio Sotomayor papers were donated to the Archives of American Art by Grace Sotomayor in 1998.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research. Patrons must use microfilm copy.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Antonio Sotomayor papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

altformavail.head: Alternative Forms Available
altformavail.p: The collection is available on microfilm reels 4792-4793. The microfilm is available for interlibrary loan.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Antonio Sotomayor papers, circa 1920-1988. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Kim Wheeler in 1993.

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence relating to Sotomayor's mural commissions, paintings and caricatures, illustrations for various publications, exhibitions at museums and galleries, and lectures. Correspondents include John Entenza, Johan Franco, Emilie Long, Grace L. McCann Morely of the San Francisco Museum of Art, José Moya del Pino, José Clemente Orozco, the Pan American Union, Alma Reed of the Delphic Studios, San Francisco mayor Elmer Robinson, Carl Sauer, Grace Sotomayor, and ethnologist Wolfgang von Hagen. There is also a folder of biographical material containing lists of some of Sotomayor's work and exhibitions from the 1920s to circa 1963.

did.unittitle: Correspondence Re: Book Illustrations, Magazines and Newspapers, 1938-1948

scopecontent.p: This series contains two notebooks of biographical notes on Latin American artists, manuscripts and copies of manuscripts on Hispanic American artists and caricature, and articles and lectures by Sotomayor. There are also writings by others on Sotomayor, and the transcript of an interview of Sotomayor conducted by Grace Moreley regarding Latin American Art.

did.unittitle: Lecture to the Sigma Delta Pi, undated
Radio Interview Transcript (in Spanish and English), circa 1939
Press Release by Edward Perkins, undated
"Bolivia Speaks in the Art of Antonio Sotomayor," by Jehane Biétry Salinger, undated
"Antonio Sotomayor" for Bulletin of the Pan American Union, by Jehane Biétry Salinger, 1933
"Sotomayor, Pintor de Bolivia" for Bulletin of the Pan American Union, by José Goméz Sicre, 1946

scopecontent.p: This series contains 130 sketches and 35 sketchbooks, mostly containing travel sketches done in South America, the Middle East, and Europe, particularly Italy. One volume contains caricatures of prominent architects. Sotomayor's mock up for the unpublished Where San Francisco Dines by Collier Connell can also be found here. See also Series 6: Oversized Material.

did.unittitle: Sketchbook of Travel Sketches, Europe, undated
Sketchbook of Travel Sketches, Italy, undated
Sketchbook of Travel Sketches, Middle East, undated
Sketchbook of Travel Sketches, South America, undated
Sketchbook of Travel Sketches, California, undated
Mock Up of Illustrations for Book Where San Francisco Dines by Collier Connell, 1935

scopecontent.p: This series contains clippings, exhibition catalogs and announcements, and several publications containing illustrations by Sotomayor.

did.unittitle: Exhibition Catalog, San Francisco Museum of Art, 1935
Exhibition Catalog, M.H. de Young Memorial Museum, 1943
Publications, The Coast and Saturday Review, 1939, 1953
Publications, The Kerlan Collection, Walter Library, University of Minnestota, 1971

scopecontent.p: Photographs found here include portraits of Sotomayor, and photographs of the artist with family and friends, including Grace Sotomayor, Fred Farr, Al Fried, William Gerstle, Lucien Labaudt, Philip Little, José Moya Del Pino, Otis Odfield, Timothy Pflueger, Diego Rivera, Pierre Salinger. There are also photographs of Sotomayor with members of the Pan American Union and the Bohemian Club, and of artwork, including some in the Sotomayor residence. See also Series 6: Oversized Material.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook of Family and Friends (loose pages), circa 1947
Photographs of Artwork in Sotomoyor Residence, circa 1952
Photograph of Bathroom Rug by Grace Sotomayor, undated

scopecontent.p: This series contains sketches, an exhibition poster, and several oversized photographs of artwork by Sotomayor and of Sotomayor with friends (duplicate of photograph in Series 5: Photographs).

did.unittitle: Sketch of Union Square Office Mural and Related Letter, 1958
Exhibition Poster for Illinois Art Gallery, undated
